text: In the seventeenth year of Pekah the son of Remaliah, Ahaz the son of Jotham, king of Judah, began to reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. And he did not do what was right in the eyes of the Lord his God, as his father David had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he walked in the way of the kings of Israel. He even burned his son as an offering, according to the despicable practices of the nations whom the Lord drove out before the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sacrificed and made offerings on the high places and on the hills and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Rezin king of Syria and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, came up to wage war on Jerusalem, and they besieged Ahaz but could not conquer him.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Rezin the king of Syria recovered Elath for Syria and drove the men of Judah from Elath, and the Edomites came to Elath, where they dwell to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahaz sent messengers to Tiglath-pileser king of Assyria, saying, “I am your servant and your son. Come up and rescue me from the hand of the king of Syria and from the hand of the king of Israel, who are attacking me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz also took the silver and gold that was found in the house of the Lord and in the treasures of the king's house and sent a present to the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Assyria listened to him. The king of Assyria marched up against Damascus and took it, carrying its people captive to Kir, and he killed Rezin.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Ahaz went to Damascus to meet Tiglath-pileser king of Assyria, he saw the altar that was at Damascus. And King Ahaz sent to Uriah the priest a model of the altar, and its pattern, exact in all its details.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Uriah the priest built the altar; in accordance with all that King Ahaz had sent from Damascus, so Uriah the priest made it, before King Ahaz arrived from Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the king came from Damascus, the king viewed the altar. Then the king drew near to the altar and went up on it
speaker: Narrator

text: and burned his burnt offering and his grain offering and poured his drink offering and threw the blood of his peace offerings on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the bronze altar that was before the Lord he removed from the front of the house, from the place between his altar and the house of the Lord, and put it on the north side of his altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And King Ahaz commanded Uriah the priest, saying, “On the great altar burn the morning burnt offering and the evening grain offering and the king's burnt offering and his grain offering, with the burnt offering of all the people of the land, and their grain offering and their drink offering. And throw on it all the blood of the burnt offering and all the blood of the sacrifice, but the bronze altar shall be for me to enquire by.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Uriah the priest did all this, as King Ahaz commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: And King Ahaz cut off the frames of the stands and removed the basin from them, and he took down the sea from off the bronze oxen that were under it and put it on a stone pedestal.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the covered way for the Sabbath that had been built inside the house and the outer entrance for the king he caused to go round the house of the Lord, because of the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Ahaz that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ahaz slept with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the city of David, and Hezekiah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah, Hoshea the son of Elah began to reign in Samaria over Israel, and he reigned for nine years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, yet not as the kings of Israel who were before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against him came up Shalmaneser king of Assyria. And Hoshea became his vassal and paid him tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Assyria found treachery in Hoshea, for he had sent messengers to So, king of Egypt, and offered no tribute to the king of Assyria, as he had done year by year. Therefore the king of Assyria shut him up and bound him in prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria invaded all the land and came to Samaria, and for three years he besieged it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the ninth year of Hoshea, the king of Assyria captured Samaria, and he carried the Israelites away to Assyria and placed them in Halah, and on the Habor, the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this occurred because the people of Israel had sinned against the Lord their God, who had brought them up out of the land of Egypt from under the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and had feared other gods
speaker: Narrator

text: and walked in the customs of the nations whom the Lord drove out before the people of Israel, and in the customs that the kings of Israel had practised.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people of Israel did secretly against the Lord their God things that were not right. They built for themselves high places in all their towns, from watchtower to fortified city.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set up for themselves pillars and Asherim on every high hill and under every green tree,
speaker: Narrator

text: and there they made offerings on all the high places, as the nations did whom the Lord carried away before them. And they did wicked things, provoking the Lord to anger,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they served idols, of which the Lord had said to them, “You shall not do this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Lord warned Israel and Judah by every prophet and every seer, saying, “Turn from your evil ways and keep my commandments and my statutes, in accordance with all the Law that I commanded your fathers, and that I sent to you by my servants the prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they would not listen, but were stubborn, as their fathers had been, who did not believe in the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They despised his statutes and his covenant that he made with their fathers and the warnings that he gave them. They went after false idols and became false, and they followed the nations that were around them, concerning whom the Lord had commanded them that they should not do like them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they abandoned all the commandments of the Lord their God, and made for themselves metal images of two calves; and they made an Asherah and worshipped all the host of heaven and served Baal.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they burned their sons and their daughters as offerings and used divination and omens and sold themselves to do evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord was very angry with Israel and removed them out of his sight. None was left but the tribe of Judah only.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah also did not keep the commandments of the Lord their God, but walked in the customs that Israel had introduced.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord rejected all the descendants of Israel and afflicted them and gave them into the hand of plunderers, until he had cast them out of his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had torn Israel from the house of David, they made Jeroboam the son of Nebat king. And Jeroboam drove Israel from following the Lord and made them commit great sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel walked in all the sins that Jeroboam did. They did not depart from them,
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Lord removed Israel out of his sight, as he had spoken by all his servants the prophets. So Israel was exiled from their own land to Assyria until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Assyria brought people from Babylon, Cuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sepharvaim, and placed them in the cities of Samaria instead of the people of Israel. And they took possession of Samaria and lived in its cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: And at the beginning of their dwelling there, they did not fear the Lord. Therefore the Lord sent lions among them, which killed some of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Assyria was told, “The nations that you have carried away and placed in the cities of Samaria do not know the law of the god of the land. Therefore he has sent lions among them, and behold, they are killing them, because they do not know the law of the god of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Assyria commanded, “Send there one of the priests whom you carried away from there, and let him go and dwell there and teach them the law of the god of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So one of the priests whom they had carried away from Samaria came and lived in Bethel and taught them how they should fear the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But every nation still made gods of its own and put them in the shrines of the high places that the Samaritans had made, every nation in the cities in which they lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Babylon made Succoth-benoth, the men of Cuth made Nergal, the men of Hamath made Ashima,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Avvites made Nibhaz and Tartak; and the Sepharvites burned their children in the fire to Adrammelech and Anammelech, the gods of Sepharvaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also feared the Lord and appointed from among themselves all sorts of people as priests of the high places, who sacrificed for them in the shrines of the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they feared the Lord but also served their own gods, after the manner of the nations from among whom they had been carried away.
speaker: Narrator

text: To this day they do according to the former manner. They do not fear the Lord, and they do not follow the statutes or the rules or the law or the commandment that the Lord commanded the children of Jacob, whom he named Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord made a covenant with them and commanded them, “You shall not fear other gods or bow yourselves to them or serve them or sacrifice to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you shall fear the Lord, who brought you out of the land of Egypt with great power and with an outstretched arm. You shall bow yourselves to him, and to him you shall sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the statutes and the rules and the law and the commandment that he wrote for you, you shall always be careful to do. You shall not fear other gods,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you shall not forget the covenant that I have made with you. You shall not fear other gods,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you shall fear the Lord your God, and he will deliver you out of the hand of all your enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, they would not listen, but they did according to their former manner.
speaker: Narrator

text: So these nations feared the Lord and also served their carved images. Their children did likewise, and their children's children—as their fathers did, so they do to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third year of Hoshea son of Elah, king of Israel, Hezekiah the son of Ahaz, king of Judah, began to reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for twenty-nine years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Abi the daughter of Zechariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was right in the eyes of the Lord, according to all that David his father had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the high places and broke the pillars and cut down the Asherah. And he broke in pieces the bronze serpent that Moses had made, for until those days the people of Israel had made offerings to it (it was called Nehushtan).
speaker: Narrator

text: He trusted in the Lord, the God of Israel, so that there was none like him among all the kings of Judah after him, nor among those who were before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he held fast to the Lord. He did not depart from following him, but kept the commandments that the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord was with him; wherever he went out, he prospered. He rebelled against the king of Assyria and would not serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck down the Philistines as far as Gaza and its territory, from watchtower to fortified city.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year of King Hezekiah, which was the seventh year of Hoshea son of Elah, king of Israel, Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against Samaria and besieged it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and at the end of three years he took it. In the sixth year of Hezekiah, which was the ninth year of Hoshea king of Israel, Samaria was taken.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Assyria carried the Israelites away to Assyria and put them in Halah, and on the Habor, the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they did not obey the voice of the Lord their God but transgressed his covenant, even all that Moses the servant of the Lord commanded. They neither listened nor obeyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and took them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah king of Judah sent to the king of Assyria at Lachish, saying, “I have done wrong; withdraw from me. Whatever you impose on me I will bear.” And the king of Assyria required of Hezekiah king of Judah three hundred talents of silver and thirty talents of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah gave him all the silver that was found in the house of the Lord and in the treasuries of the king's house.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Hezekiah stripped the gold from the doors of the temple of the Lord and from the doorposts that Hezekiah king of Judah had overlaid and gave it to the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Assyria sent the Tartan, the Rab-saris, and the Rabshakeh with a great army from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. And they went up and came to Jerusalem. When they arrived, they came and stood by the conduit of the upper pool, which is on the highway to the Washer's Field.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they called for the king, there came out to them Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebnah the secretary, and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Rabshakeh said to them, “Say to Hezekiah, ‘Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: On what do you rest this trust of yours?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you think that mere words are strategy and power for war? In whom do you now trust, that you have rebelled against me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, you are trusting now in Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of any man who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who trust in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you say to me, “We trust in the Lord our God”, is it not he whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, “You shall worship before this altar in Jerusalem”?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able on your part to set riders on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: How then can you repulse a single captain among the least of my master's servants, when you trust in Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, is it without the Lord that I have come up against this place to destroy it? The Lord said to me, Go up against this land, and destroy it.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, and Shebnah, and Joah, said to the Rabshakeh, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it. Do not speak to us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Rabshakeh said to them, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you, and not to the men sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and to drink their own urine?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah: “Hear the word of the great king, the king of Assyria!
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the king: ‘Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you out of my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not let Hezekiah make you trust in the Lord by saying, The Lord will surely deliver us, and this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not listen to Hezekiah, for thus says the king of Assyria: ‘Make your peace with me and come out to me. Then each one of you will eat of his own vine, and each one of his own fig tree, and each one of you will drink the water of his own cistern,
speaker: Narrator

text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards, a land of olive trees and honey, that you may live, and not die. And do not listen to Hezekiah when he misleads you by saying, The Lord will deliver us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has any of the gods of the nations ever delivered his land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah? Have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who among all the gods of the lands have delivered their lands out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were silent and answered him not a word, for the king's command was, “Do not answer him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth and went into the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sent Eliakim, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah the son of Amoz.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah, This day is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace; children have come to the point of birth, and there is no strength to bring them forth.
speaker: Narrator

text: It may be that the Lord your God heard all the words of the Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words that the Lord your God has heard; therefore lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Isaiah said to them, “Say to your master, ‘Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid because of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have reviled me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, I will put a spirit in him, so that he shall hear a rumour and return to his own land, and I will make him fall by the sword in his own land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Rabshakeh returned, and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, for he heard that the king had left Lachish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king heard concerning Tirhakah king of Cush, “Behold, he has set out to fight against you.” So he sent messengers again to Hezekiah, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus shall you speak to Hezekiah king of Judah: ‘Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands, devoting them to destruction. And shall you be delivered?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them, the nations that my fathers destroyed, Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, the king of Hena, or the king of Ivvah?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it; and Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord and spread it before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah prayed before the Lord and said: “O Lord, the God of Israel, enthroned above the cherubim, you are the God, you alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth; you have made heaven and earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Incline your ear, O Lord, and hear; open your eyes, O Lord, and see; and hear the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to mock the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Truly, O Lord, the kings of Assyria have laid waste the nations and their lands
speaker: Narrator

text: and have cast their gods into the fire, for they were not gods, but the work of men's hands, wood and stone. Therefore they were destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, O Lord our God, save us, please, from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you, O Lord, are God alone.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah the son of Amoz sent to Hezekiah, saying, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Your prayer to me about Sennacherib king of Assyria I have heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the word that the Lord has spoken concerning him:
“She despises you, she scorns you—
    the virgin daughter of Zion;
she wags her head behind you—
    the daughter of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Whom have you mocked and reviled?
    Against whom have you raised your voice
and lifted your eyes to the heights?
    Against the Holy One of Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text:
By your messengers you have mocked the Lord,
    and you have said, ‘With my many chariots
I have gone up the heights of the mountains,
    to the far recesses of Lebanon;
I felled its tallest cedars,
    its choicest cypresses;
I entered its farthest lodging place,
    its most fruitful forest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I dug wells
    and drank foreign waters,
and I dried up with the sole of my foot
    all the streams of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you not heard
    that I determined it long ago?
I planned from days of old
    what now I bring to pass,
that you should turn fortified cities
    into heaps of ruins,
speaker: Narrator

text:
while their inhabitants, shorn of strength,
    are dismayed and confounded,
and have become like plants of the field
    and like tender grass,
like grass on the housetops,
    blighted before it is grown.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But I know your sitting down
    and your going out and coming in,
    and your raging against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you have raged against me
    and your complacency has come into my ears,
I will put my hook in your nose
    and my bit in your mouth,
and I will turn you back on the way
    by which you came.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And this shall be the sign for you: this year eat what grows of itself, and in the second year what springs of the same. Then in the third year sow and reap and plant vineyards, and eat their fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the surviving remnant of the house of Judah shall again take root downwards and bear fruit upwards.
speaker: Narrator

text: For out of Jerusalem shall go a remnant, and out of Mount Zion a band of survivors. The zeal of the Lord will do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not come into this city or shoot an arrow there, or come before it with a shield or cast up a siege mound against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the way that he came, by the same he shall return, and he shall not come into this city, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will defend this city to save it, for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And that night the angel of the Lord went out and struck down 185,000 in the camp of the Assyrians. And when people arose early in the morning, behold, these were all dead bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sennacherib king of Assyria departed and went home and lived at Nineveh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as he was worshipping in the house of Nisroch his god, Adrammelech and Sharezer, his sons, struck him down with the sword and escaped into the land of Ararat. And Esarhaddon his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days Hezekiah became sick and was at the point of death. And Isaiah the prophet the son of Amoz came to him and said to him, “Thus says the Lord, ‘Set your house in order, for you shall die; you shall not recover.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, O Lord, please remember how I have walked before you in faithfulness and with a whole heart, and have done what is good in your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: And before Isaiah had gone out of the middle court, the word of the Lord came to him:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Turn back, and say to Hezekiah the leader of my people, Thus says the Lord, the God of David your father: I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears. Behold, I will heal you. On the third day you shall go up to the house of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will add fifteen years to your life. I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria, and I will defend this city for my own sake and for my servant David's sake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaiah said, “Bring a cake of figs. And let them take and lay it on the boil, that he may recover.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “What shall be the sign that the Lord will heal me, and that I shall go up to the house of the Lord on the third day?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaiah said, “This shall be the sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do the thing that he has promised: shall the shadow go forward ten steps, or go back ten steps?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah answered, “It is an easy thing for the shadow to lengthen ten steps. Rather let the shadow go back ten steps.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaiah the prophet called to the Lord, and he brought the shadow back ten steps, by which it had gone down on the steps of Ahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Merodach-baladan the son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent envoys with letters and a present to Hezekiah, for he heard that Hezekiah had been sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah welcomed them, and he showed them all his treasure house, the silver, the gold, the spices, the precious oil, his armoury, all that was found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his house or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah, and said to him, “What did these men say? And from where did they come to you?” And Hezekiah said, “They have come from a far country, from Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “What have they seen in your house?” And Hezekiah answered, “They have seen all that is in my house; there is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the days are coming, when all that is in your house, and that which your fathers have stored up till this day, shall be carried to Babylon. Nothing shall be left, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And some of your own sons, who shall be born to you, shall be taken away, and they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said Hezekiah to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “Why not, if there will be peace and security in my days?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the deeds of Hezekiah and all his might and how he made the pool and the conduit and brought water into the city, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hezekiah slept with his fathers, and Manasseh his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh was twelve years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for fifty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hephzibah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, according to the despicable practices of the nations whom the Lord drove out before the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he rebuilt the high places that Hezekiah his father had destroyed, and he erected altars for Baal and made an Asherah, as Ahab king of Israel had done, and worshipped all the host of heaven and served them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he built altars in the house of the Lord, of which the Lord had said, “In Jerusalem will I put my name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he built altars for all the host of heaven in the two courts of the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he burned his son as an offering and used fortune-telling and omens and dealt with mediums and with necromancers. He did much evil in the sight of the Lord, provoking him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the carved image of Asherah that he had made he set in the house of which the Lord said to David and to Solomon his son, “In this house, and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, I will put my name for ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will not cause the feet of Israel to wander any more out of the land that I gave to their fathers, if only they will be careful to do according to all that I have commanded them, and according to all the Law that my servant Moses commanded them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen, and Manasseh led them astray to do more evil than the nations had done whom the Lord destroyed before the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said by his servants the prophets,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Because Manasseh king of Judah has committed these abominations and has done things more evil than all that the Amorites did, who were before him, and has made Judah also to sin with his idols,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Behold, I am bringing upon Jerusalem and Judah such disaster that the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line of Samaria, and the plumb line of the house of Ahab, and I will wipe Jerusalem as one wipes a dish, wiping it and turning it upside down.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will forsake the remnant of my heritage and give them into the hand of their enemies, and they shall become a prey and a spoil to all their enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they have done what is evil in my sight and have provoked me to anger, since the day their fathers came out of Egypt, even to this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Manasseh shed very much innocent blood, till he had filled Jerusalem from one end to another, besides the sin that he made Judah to sin so that they did what was evil in the sight of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Manasseh and all that he did, and the sin that he committed, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: And Manasseh slept with his fathers and was buried in the garden of his house, in the garden of Uzza, and Amon his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amon was twenty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for two years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Meshullemeth the daughter of Haruz of Jotbah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, as Manasseh his father had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in all the way in which his father walked and served the idols that his father served and worshipped them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He abandoned the Lord, the God of his fathers, and did not walk in the way of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the servants of Amon conspired against him and put the king to death in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people of the land struck down all those who had conspired against King Amon, and the people of the land made Josiah his son king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Amon that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: And he was buried in his tomb in the garden of Uzza, and Josiah his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for thirty-one years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jedidah the daughter of Adaiah of Bozkath.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was right in the eyes of the Lord and walked in all the way of David his father, and he did not turn aside to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eighteenth year of King Josiah, the king sent Shaphan the son of Azaliah, son of Meshullam, the secretary, to the house of the Lord, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go up to Hilkiah the high priest, that he may count the money that has been brought into the house of the Lord, which the keepers of the threshold have collected from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let it be given into the hand of the workmen who have the oversight of the house of the Lord, and let them give it to the workmen who are at the house of the Lord, repairing the house
speaker: Narrator

text: (that is, to the carpenters, and to the builders, and to the masons), and let them use it for buying timber and quarried stone to repair the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But no accounting shall be asked from them for the money that is delivered into their hand, for they deal honestly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Hilkiah the high priest said to Shaphan the secretary, “I have found the Book of the Law in the house of the Lord.” And Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan, and he read it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Shaphan the secretary came to the king, and reported to the king, “Your servants have emptied out the money that was found in the house and have delivered it into the hand of the workmen who have the oversight of the house of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shaphan the secretary told the king, “Hilkiah the priest has given me a book.” And Shaphan read it before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard the words of the Book of the Law, he tore his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king commanded Hilkiah the priest, and Ahikam the son of Shaphan, and Achbor the son of Micaiah, and Shaphan the secretary, and Asaiah the king's servant, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go, enquire of the Lord for me, and for the people, and for all Judah, concerning the words of this book that has been found. For great is the wrath of the Lord that is kindled against us, because our fathers have not obeyed the words of this book, to do according to all that is written concerning us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hilkiah the priest, and Ahikam, and Achbor, and Shaphan, and Asaiah went to Huldah the prophetess, the wife of Shallum the son of Tikvah, son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe (now she lived in Jerusalem in the Second Quarter), and they talked with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to them, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: ‘Tell the man who sent you to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the Lord, Behold, I will bring disaster upon this place and upon its inhabitants, all the words of the book that the king of Judah has read.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because they have forsaken me and have made offerings to other gods, that they might provoke me to anger with all the work of their hands, therefore my wrath will be kindled against this place, and it will not be quenched.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to the king of Judah, who sent you to enquire of the Lord, thus shall you say to him, Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Regarding the words that you have heard,
speaker: Narrator

text: because your heart was penitent, and you humbled yourself before the Lord, when you heard how I spoke against this place and against its inhabitants, that they should become a desolation and a curse, and you have torn your clothes and wept before me, I also have heard you, declares the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, behold, I will gather you to your fathers, and you shall be gathered to your grave in peace, and your eyes shall not see all the disaster that I will bring upon this place.’” And they brought back word to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king sent, and all the elders of Judah and Jerusalem were gathered to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king went up to the house of the Lord, and with him all the men of Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem and the priests and the prophets, all the people, both small and great. And he read in their hearing all the words of the Book of the Covenant that had been found in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king stood by the pillar and made a covenant before the Lord, to walk after the Lord and to keep his commandments and his testimonies and his statutes with all his heart and all his soul, to perform the words of this covenant that were written in this book. And all the people joined in the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king commanded Hilkiah the high priest and the priests of the second order and the keepers of the threshold to bring out of the temple of the Lord all the vessels made for Baal, for Asherah, and for all the host of heaven. He burned them outside Jerusalem in the fields of the Kidron and carried their ashes to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he deposed the priests whom the kings of Judah had ordained to make offerings in the high places at the cities of Judah and round Jerusalem; those also who burned incense to Baal, to the sun and the moon and the constellations and all the host of the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he brought out the Asherah from the house of the Lord, outside Jerusalem, to the brook Kidron, and burned it at the brook Kidron and beat it to dust and cast the dust of it upon the graves of the common people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he broke down the houses of the male cult prostitutes who were in the house of the Lord, where the women wove hangings for the Asherah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he brought all the priests out of the cities of Judah, and defiled the high places where the priests had made offerings, from Geba to Beersheba. And he broke down the high places of the gates that were at the entrance of the gate of Joshua the governor of the city, which were on one's left at the gate of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the priests of the high places did not come up to the altar of the Lord in Jerusalem, but they ate unleavened bread among their brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he defiled Topheth, which is in the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, that no one might burn his son or his daughter as an offering to Molech.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he removed the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun, at the entrance to the house of the Lord, by the chamber of Nathan-melech the chamberlain, which was in the precincts. And he burned the chariots of the sun with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the altars on the roof of the upper chamber of Ahaz, which the kings of Judah had made, and the altars that Manasseh had made in the two courts of the house of the Lord, he pulled down and broke in pieces and cast the dust of them into the brook Kidron.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king defiled the high places that were east of Jerusalem, to the south of the mount of corruption, which Solomon the king of Israel had built for Ashtoreth the abomination of the Sidonians, and for Chemosh the abomination of Moab, and for Milcom the abomination of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he broke in pieces the pillars and cut down the Asherim and filled their places with the bones of men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the altar at Bethel, the high place erected by Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who made Israel to sin, that altar with the high place he pulled down and burned, reducing it to dust. He also burned the Asherah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as Josiah turned, he saw the tombs there on the mount. And he sent and took the bones out of the tombs and burned them on the altar and defiled it, according to the word of the Lord that the man of God proclaimed, who had predicted these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “What is that monument that I see?” And the men of the city told him, “It is the tomb of the man of God who came from Judah and predicted these things that you have done against the altar at Bethel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Let him be; let no man move his bones.” So they left his bones alone, with the bones of the prophet who came out of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Josiah removed all the shrines also of the high places that were in the cities of Samaria, which kings of Israel had made, provoking the Lord to anger. He did to them according to all that he had done at Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sacrificed all the priests of the high places who were there, on the altars, and burned human bones on them. Then he returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king commanded all the people, “Keep the Passover to the Lord your God, as it is written in this Book of the Covenant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For no such Passover had been kept since the days of the judges who judged Israel, or during all the days of the kings of Israel or of the kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the eighteenth year of King Josiah this Passover was kept to the Lord in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Josiah put away the mediums and the necromancers and the household gods and the idols and all the abominations that were seen in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem, that he might establish the words of the law that were written in the book that Hilkiah the priest found in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Before him there was no king like him, who turned to the Lord with all his heart and with all his soul and with all his might, according to all the Law of Moses, nor did any like him arise after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still the Lord did not turn from the burning of his great wrath, by which his anger was kindled against Judah, because of all the provocations with which Manasseh had provoked him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “I will remove Judah also out of my sight, as I have removed Israel, and I will cast off this city that I have chosen, Jerusalem, and the house of which I said, My name shall be there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Josiah and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days Pharaoh Neco king of Egypt went up to the king of Assyria to the river Euphrates. King Josiah went to meet him, and Pharaoh Neco killed him at Megiddo, as soon as he saw him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his servants carried him dead in a chariot from Megiddo and brought him to Jerusalem and buried him in his own tomb. And the people of the land took Jehoahaz the son of Josiah, and anointed him, and made him king in his father's place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that his fathers had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh Neco put him in bonds at Riblah in the land of Hamath, that he might not reign in Jerusalem, and laid on the land a tribute of a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh Neco made Eliakim the son of Josiah king in the place of Josiah his father, and changed his name to Jehoiakim. But he took Jehoahaz away, and he came to Egypt and died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jehoiakim gave the silver and the gold to Pharaoh, but he taxed the land to give the money according to the command of Pharaoh. He exacted the silver and the gold of the people of the land, from everyone according to his assessment, to give it to Pharaoh Neco.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zebidah the daughter of Pedaiah of Rumah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that his fathers had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: In his days, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up, and Jehoiakim became his servant for three years. Then he turned and rebelled against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord sent against him bands of the Chaldeans and bands of the Syrians and bands of the Moabites and bands of the Ammonites, and sent them against Judah to destroy it, according to the word of the Lord that he spoke by his servants the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely this came upon Judah at the command of the Lord, to remove them out of his sight, for the sins of Manasseh, according to all that he had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: and also for the innocent blood that he had shed. For he filled Jerusalem with innocent blood, and the Lord would not pardon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jehoiakim and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiakim slept with his fathers, and Jehoiachin his son reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Egypt did not come again out of his land, for the king of Babylon had taken all that belonged to the king of Egypt from the Brook of Egypt to the river Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king, and he reigned for three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Nehushta the daughter of Elnathan of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that his father had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the servants of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up to Jerusalem, and the city was besieged.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came to the city while his servants were besieging it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Jehoiachin the king of Judah gave himself up to the king of Babylon, himself and his mother and his servants and his officials and his palace officials. The king of Babylon took him prisoner in the eighth year of his reign
speaker: Narrator

text: and carried off all the treasures of the house of the Lord and the treasures of the king's house, and cut in pieces all the vessels of gold in the temple of the Lord, which Solomon king of Israel had made, as the Lord had foretold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carried away all Jerusalem and all the officials and all the mighty men of valour, 10,000 captives, and all the craftsmen and the smiths. None remained, except the poorest people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he carried away Jehoiachin to Babylon. The king's mother, the king's wives, his officials, and the chief men of the land he took into captivity from Jerusalem to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Babylon brought captive to Babylon all the men of valour, 7,000, and the craftsmen and the metal workers, 1,000, all of them strong and fit for war.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Babylon made Mattaniah, Jehoiachin's uncle, king in his place, and changed his name to Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, according to all that Jehoiakim had done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For because of the anger of the Lord it came to the point in Jerusalem and Judah that he cast them out from his presence.
And Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came with all his army against Jerusalem and laid siege to it. And they built siege works all round it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the city was besieged till the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the ninth day of the fourth month the famine was so severe in the city that there was no food for the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a breach was made in the city, and all the men of war fled by night by the way of the gate between the two walls, by the king's garden, though the Chaldeans were round the city. And they went in the direction of the Arabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the army of the Chaldeans pursued the king and overtook him in the plains of Jericho, and all his army was scattered from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they captured the king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah, and they passed sentence on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They slaughtered the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes, and put out the eyes of Zedekiah and bound him in chains and took him to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth month, on the seventh day of the month—that was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon—Nebuzaradan, the captain of the bodyguard, a servant of the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he burned the house of the Lord and the king's house and all the houses of Jerusalem; every great house he burned down.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the army of the Chaldeans, who were with the captain of the guard, broke down the walls round Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the rest of the people who were left in the city and the deserters who had deserted to the king of Babylon, together with the rest of the multitude, Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the captain of the guard left some of the poorest of the land to be vine dressers and ploughmen.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the pillars of bronze that were in the house of the Lord, and the stands and the bronze sea that were in the house of the Lord, the Chaldeans broke in pieces and carried the bronze to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they took away the pots and the shovels and the snuffers and the dishes for incense and all the vessels of bronze used in the temple service,
speaker: Narrator

text: the firepans also and the bowls. What was of gold the captain of the guard took away as gold, and what was of silver, as silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the two pillars, the one sea, and the stands that Solomon had made for the house of the Lord, the bronze of all these vessels was beyond weight.
speaker: Narrator

text: The height of one pillar was eighteen cubits, and on it was a capital of bronze. The height of the capital was three cubits. A latticework and pomegranates, all of bronze, were all round the capital. And the second pillar had the same, with the latticework.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the captain of the guard took Seraiah the chief priest and Zephaniah the second priest and the three keepers of the threshold,
speaker: Narrator

text: and from the city he took an officer who had been in command of the men of war, and five men of the king's council who were found in the city, and the secretary of the commander of the army who mustered the people of the land, and sixty men of the people of the land who were found in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death at Riblah in the land of Hamath. So Judah was taken into exile out of its land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And over the people who remained in the land of Judah, whom Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon had left, he appointed Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when all the captains and their men heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah governor, they came with their men to Gedaliah at Mizpah, namely, Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and Johanan the son of Kareah, and Seraiah the son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah the son of the Maacathite.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gedaliah swore to them and their men, saying, “Do not be afraid because of the Chaldean officials. Live in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it shall be well with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the seventh month, Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, of the royal family, came with ten men and struck down Gedaliah and put him to death along with the Jews and the Chaldeans who were with him at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people, both small and great, and the captains of the forces arose and went to Egypt, for they were afraid of the Chaldeans.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, Evil-merodach king of Babylon, in the year that he began to reign, graciously freed Jehoiachin king of Judah from prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat above the seats of the kings who were with him in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiachin put off his prison garments. And every day of his life he dined regularly at the king's table,
speaker: Narrator

text: and for his allowance, a regular allowance was given him by the king, according to his daily needs, as long as he lived.
speaker: Narrator
